a.g: Or have they other deities who have ordained for them a religion to which Allah has not consented? But if not for the decisive word, it would have been concluded between them. And indeed, the wrongdoers will have a painful punishment.

You will see the wrongdoers fearful of what they have earned, and it will [certainly] befall them. And those who have believed and done righteous deeds will be in lush regions of the gardens [in Paradise] having whatever they will in the presence of their Lord. That is what is the great bounty.

It is that of which Allah gives good tidings to His servants who believe and do righteous deeds. Say, [O Muhammad], "I do not ask you for this message any payment [but] only good will through kinship." And whoever commits a good deed - We will increase for him good therein. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Appreciative.

Or do they say, "He has invented about Allah a lie"? But if Allah willed, He could seal over your heart. And Allah eliminates falsehood and establishes the truth by His words. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts.
And it is He who accepts repentance from his servants and pardons misdeeds, and He knows what you do.
And He answers [the supplication of] those who have believed and done righteous deeds and increases [for] them from His bounty. But the disbelievers will have a severe punishment.

And if Allah had extended [excessively] provision for His servants, they would have committed tyranny throughout the earth. But He sends [it] down in an amount which He wills. Indeed He is, of His servants, Acquainted and Seeing.

Indeed, if Allah had expanded provision [ar-rizq] for His servants, they would have transgressed in the earth. And indeed, man becomes insolent when he sees himself self-sufficient. And indeed, Allah protects His believing servant from the world [ad-dunya] while He loves him, just as one of you protects his sick one. And likewise, the wife, the child, the relative, and everything we have mentioned in the sixteen categories of blessings besides faith [iman] and good character [husn al-khuluq]â€”it is conceivable that they become a trial [bala'] for some people, so their opposites then become blessings [ni'mah] for them. For it preceded that knowledge [ma'rifah] is a perfection and a blessing, as it is an attribute from the attributes of Allah, the Exalted. But it may be upon the servant in some matters a trial, and its absence a blessing. Its example is the ignorance [jahl] of a person concerning his appointed term [ajal]; indeed, it is a blessing for him, for if he knew it, perhaps his life would become bitter and his grief would thereby be prolonged. And likewise, his ignorance of what his acquaintances and relatives harbor against him is a blessing for him, for if the veil [as-sitr] were lifted and he became aware of it, his pain, his rancor, and his envy would be prolonged, and he would be preoccupied with revenge. And likewise, his ignorance of the blameworthy attributes in others is a blessing for him, for if he knew them, he would hate him and harm him, and that would be a calamity upon him in this world [ad-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhirah]. Rather, his ignorance of the praiseworthy attributes in others may be a blessing for him, for perhaps he is a friend [wali] of Allah, the Exalted, and he is compelled to harm and insult him. And if he knew that and harmed him, his sin would undoubtedly be greater. For he who harms a prophet or a friend while knowing is not like he who harms while not knowing. And from them is Allah, the Exalted, making the matter of the Resurrection ambiguous, and His making the Night of Decree ambiguous, and the hour of Friday ambiguous, and His making some of the major sins ambiguous. All of that is a blessing, because this ignorance [jahl] increases your motives for seeking and striving. These are aspects of Allah's blessings in ignorance, so how about in knowledge [al-'ilm]? And since we said that for Allah, the Exalted, in every existent thing there is a blessing, that is true. And that applies to everyone, and none is excluded from it by mere conjecture except the pains which He creates in some people. And they also may be a blessing for the one who suffers them. And if they are not a blessing for him, like the pain resulting from sin, such as him cutting his own hand or tattooing his skin, then he suffers from it while he is sinful in it. And the pain of the disbelievers in the Fire is also a blessing, but for others among the servants, not for them. For the misfortunes of one people are benefits for another people. And were it not that Allah, the Exalted, created punishment and punished a group with it, those enjoying comfort would not know the measure of His blessings, even if their joy in them increased. For the joy of the people of Paradise only multiplies when they reflect upon the pains of the people of the Fire. Do you not see the people of this world [ad-dunya]? Their joy in the light of the sun does not intensify, despite their severe need for it, because it is universal and freely given. And their joy in looking at the adornment of the sky does not intensify, though it is more beautiful than every garden they have on earth which they strive to cultivate. But because the adornment of the sky is universal, they do not perceive it and do not rejoice because of it. Therefore, what we mentioned has been confirmed: that Allah, the Exalted, did not create anything except that in it is wisdom [hikmah], and He did not create anything except that in it is a blessing [ni'mah], either for all His servants or for some of them. Therefore, in Allah's creation of the trial [al-bala'] there is also a blessing, either for the one afflicted or for other than the one afflicted. Therefore, every state cannot be described as an absolute trial nor an absolute blessing. So two duties converge upon the servant in it: patience [as-sabr] and gratitude [ash-shukr] together.

Know that the honor of the intellect [al-'aql] is something that requires no strain to manifest, especially since the honor of knowledge [al-'ilm] has already become apparent through the intellect. The intellect is the source [manba'] of knowledge, its point of emergence [matla'], and its foundation [asas]. Knowledge flows from it as fruit flows from a tree, light [nur] from the sun, and sight from the eye. How then can that which is the means to felicity [sa'ada] in this world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhira] not be honored? Or how can there be doubt concerning it, when even the beast, with its deficient discernment, holds the intellect in awe? Indeed, the greatest of beasts in body, the most ferocious in savagery, and the strongest in mightâ€”when it sees the form of a human, it holds him in awe and fears him due to its sensing his mastery over it, because of what he is specifically endowed with: the perception of stratagems. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The elder [al-shaykh] among his people is like a prophet among his nation." This is not due to the abundance of his wealth, nor the grandeur of his person, nor the increase of his strength, but rather due to the increase of his experience, which is the fruit of his intellect. Therefore, you see the Turks, the Kurds, the uncouth Bedouin Arabs, and the rest of creationâ€”despite the proximity of their station to the rank of beastsâ€”by their very nature revere the elders. For this reason, when many of the stubbornly defiant intended to kill the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and their eyes fell upon him and were adorned by his noble countenance, they were in awe of him. That which gleamed upon the brocade of his faceâ€”the light [nur] of prophethoodâ€”became visible to them, even though that was inwardly hidden within his soul [nafs] with the hiddenness of the intellect. Thus, the honor of the intellect is perceived by necessity. The intent here is only to relate what has come in the reports and the verses concerning the mention of its honor. And God has named it a light [nur] in His saying, the Exalted: "God is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The parable of His Light is as a niche..." And He named the knowledge derived from it a spirit [ruh], a revelation [wahy], and a life [hayah]. Thus He, the Exalted, said: "And thus have We revealed to you a spirit from Our command..." And He, the Glorified, said: "Or one who was dead, and We gave him life and made for him a light by which he walks among the people..." And wherever He mentions light [nur] and darkness [zulmah], He intends by it knowledge [al-'ilm] and ignorance [al-jahl], like His saying: "He brings them out from darknesses into the light."
